The word "in" can have multiple translations in Finnish depending on its context. Here are a few possible translations:

1. "In" as a preposition indicating location: "sisällä"
Example: The cat is in the house. - Kissa on talossa.

2. "In" as a preposition indicating time: "aikana"
Example: I will see you in the evening. - Näen sinut illalla.

3. "In" as an adverb indicating inclusion: "mukana"
Example: She brought her dog in. - Hän toi koiransa mukanaan.

Please provide more context if you need a more specific translation.
